snippet: In a society where headlines of violence are almost commonplace, the families of the perpetrators are largely unheard from. But now some relatives have decided to share their stories.
abstract: Relatives of violent criminals and murderers are largely unheard from, although they suffer from shame, anger and guilt and are overwhelmed by the blame and ostracism they have received for crimes they had no part in; interviews with the family members of several high-profile killers underscore the hardships they have experienced in the years since their relatives' crimes.

byline.contributor: Research was contributed by Jack Styczynski, Toby Lyles and Sheelagh McNeill.

lead_paragraph: In a society where headlines of violence are almost commonplace, the families of the perpetrators are largely unheard from. But now some relatives have decided to share their stories.

headline.main: Killers’ Families Left to Confront Fear and Shame
